There is a bug in 2.4.x which affects users upgrading from 2.0.x or earlier, using a license over 1 year old.  In the screen prompting to enter an updated license key or switch to "evaluation" mode, submitting the form results in a "User does not have administration permission" error.

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-2328].
  {panel}

Details on the report below - from Jesco von Voss:

> I'm not sure quite how the second report works. Given a particular version,
> list all the time assigned to different developers? How does the calendar
> date part work?

The idea is this: I want to know how much buffer time we have until
a version is due. And a version is due on a release date, which is given
by calendar date, not by the expression "in 45 work days".

So I have a developer and sum up her current work load in days and hours,
based on all issues assigned to her. (Minus the time worked on the issues,
of course. And across all projects.) That is the first report I described.

Now I give a calendar date, and the system should figure out how many
days the developer will be in the office. How many times will the sun
rise, minus all Saturdays and Sundays. That's how many days she has left
to complete her work load. The difference is the buffer time for her.
As you already have popups in date input fields that show the month,
formatted by weeks, I imagine calculating the office days would not be
too hard.
Let's ignore July 4 or any other holidays for now.

Ideally, one would like to see this for all developers in an overview page
(Or maybe for all developers that are assigned to a project? ) But a start
would be to show this on the start page for every developer.

The question is how this "release date" would be stored. Ideally, I would
like to set one project as being the reference in the global Administration
settings somewhere. Then, the system would get that project, get the next
upcoming version, and retrieve its "release date" value, which I have set
appropriately.

The fast version of implementing this would probably be to just set a
"release date" somewhere in the Administration settings and use that value.

There is a slight mismatch, as you might have noticed: I want the workload
of a developer gathered across all projects, but one project should be
used to determine how much time is left. But that's how we work ... we'd
like to set up one project "Holidays", one project "Fairs + Exhibitions",
and everyone would log issues there. This way we know: "Person A has two
days off, is one day at a conference, and has 14 days worth of issues,
that gives him two days left until day X, and that's ok".
fields.summary: Developer free time report, given a date

fields.description:

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-2326].
  {panel}

This is a 'meta-issue' for linking all issues related to advanced email support.  That is, towards being able to use email as a primary JIRA interface -- ideally, not even be aware that JIRA is involved.

The biggest use-case I have is public opensource projects.  All communication happens over email, and there is very little distinction between an email and an issue, neither conceptually nor physically (the tracker is configured to send emails for new issues/comments). Frequently, long conversations are held via comments in an issue [1]

For established projects, a significant proportion (~40%) of non-cvs emails are generated by the issue tracker.  It would be a _massive_ timesaver if developers didn't need to run off to a web interface to comment on issues.

JIRA has some rudimentary support for this (CreateOrCommentHandler), but JIRA-generated emails:
 - do not support threading (JRA-1113)
 - are IMHO pretty ugly and not easy to scan quickly compared to Bugzilla's. (JRA-3719)
 - do not customize the From: address to indicate who the commenter is. (JRA-2315)

So I think getting decent email support would be a fantastic way of capturing the lucrative open-source market.  More than any other feature, it would leapfrog JIRA over its competitors.

----

If JIRA's email support was enhanced sufficiently, it could also be used as a support system backend, tracking support requests, not least here at Atlassian.  This is a whole new market, probably justifying a new product stream, but I think the enhancements mentioned above would give us an 80:20 solution.


--Jeff


[1] For example, see some of Mozilla's longer threads, like http://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=97284 .
fields.summary: Advanced email support

fields.description:
I'm not sure if this bug is fixed with the JRA-1520 issue, but if not I just report it here.

This is an example case describing the problem:

1. I have some issues that either have the "Affected Versions" or "Fix Versions" field set to version 2.3.21.

2. I rename version 2.3.21 to 2.4.0 in the project management area.

3. When looking at the roadmap the issues now seem to be related to the new name (2.4.0), but when clicking on one of the issues it still says 2.3.21 in either the "Affected Versions" or "Fix Versions" field.
fields.summary: Renamed version name does not show in related issues

fields.description:
Currently its not possible to see what Permission Schemes a user Group is being used for.

1) This means its difficult to work out if a group is not being used at all (makes it hard to clean up groups - something required over time).

2) This means its difficult to audit what permissions a given user has.
You can see what groups they are a member of - but then you have to go through all the permission schemes to see where (if at all) each group is being used.

3) Its not easy to spot a group being used in the wrong permission scheme.
Perhaps the result of a mistake - it means that suddenly a user can see a project (or a whole lot of projects) that they shouldnt.
fields.summary: View what permission schemes a group is used in

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-2314].
  {panel}

The workflow of Issue working may have some order. For example PM post new issues to project and want to see it in project plan.

We need now use follow workaround. First we separate project by versions as project stages. We post issue and set "Fix for Version", and choose version for planed fixing issue. To ordering in versions we using priority. In result we have roadmap:
1.0.1
  Issue 01
  Issue 02
1.0.2
  Issue 03
  Issue 04
1.0.3
  Issue 05
  Issue 06
1.0.4
  Issue 07
  Issue 08

But we need follow:
Issue must have link to depended issues (how we use for it link "Depends", we linking depended issues but it not affected on issues ordering in Road Map).
In Road Map, firstly show independed issues, follow its depends indended by space. The road map must look like a tree.
For example:
Road Map:
1.0.1
  Issue 01
    Issue 02
    Issue 03
  Issue 04
  Issue 05
    Issue 06
    Issue 07
1.0.2
  Issue 08
    Issue 09
  Issue 10

Issues in one level will ordered as now in roadmap - by priority.

Thanks!

  {panel}

It sure would be great if the emails indicated WHY you received the message.  Something like:
-  You received this message because you are assigned the issue
-  You received this message because you are the previous assignee for the issue
-  You received this message because you changed the issue
-  You received this message because you reported the issue
-  You received this message because you are watching the issue
-  You received this message because you are the project lead


It would be even better if this information were available in the Subject or another email header so it is easy to filter on.

fields.description:
I have tried importing bugzilla into 2.3 (since 2.4.1 being broken is a known bug).

I have problems with the following:
- most web browsers/proxies seem to timeout on a request that takes this  long (an hour or more with a large bugzilla database). To get around this, I do a GET request on the bugzilla import using a tool that controls/ignores the timeout, and send the JSESSIONID cookie so it will log in.
- I get the following exception, presumable because the session timeout is less than the length of time it takes.
[10:09:56] java.lang.IllegalStateException: getAttribute: Session already invalidated
        at org.apache.catalina.session.StandardSession.getAttribute(StandardSession.java:954)
        at org.apache.catalina.session.StandardSessionFacade.getAttribute(StandardSessionFacade.java:171)
        at webwork.action.factory.SessionMap.get(SessionMap.java:86)
        at com.atlassian.jira.web.action.JiraWebActionSupport.getRemoteUser(JiraWebActionSupport.java:51)
        at com.atlassian.jira.web.action.util.BugzillaImport.createChangeHistory(BugzillaImport.java:335)
        at com.atlassian.jira.web.action.util.BugzillaImport.createIssue(BugzillaImport.java:271)
        at com.atlassian.jira.web.action.util.BugzillaImport.createIssues(BugzillaImport.java:210)
        at com.atlassian.jira.web.action.util.BugzillaImport.doExecute(BugzillaImport.java:132)
        at webwork.action.ActionSupport.execute(ActionSupport.java:116)

I would suggest that the bugzilla -> XML process should be a separate Java application, and this XML should then be imported via the regular JIRA mechanism.

I rate this as major as it could potentially push our company's decision to adopt JIRA over our existing bugzilla installation into the negative. We are currently evaluating it.
fields.summary: bugzilla issues with timeouts

fields.description:
For timetracking to work effectively, the underlying data must be consistent. This means that developers have to log their work for timetracking reports to be meaningful.

Request: prevent resolving an issue if timetracking is enabled, work logged == 0 and resolution != duplicate, so developers are forced to log their work.
fields.summary: TimeTracking: Prevent resolving issue without logging work

fields.description:
If JIRA's encoding is set to something like 'ISO8859_1', then the XML export apparently fails, because the encoding declaration is invalid:

/tmp/export.xml:1: error: Unsupported encoding ISO8859_1
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="ISO8859_1"?>

The workaround is simply to use 'iso-8859-1' as the encoding, which is valid for XML and Java.
fields.summary: XML export created with invalid encoding declaration

fields.description: The "Assigned to me" link should cause issue navigator to display ALL open issues, including "reopened" issues (which it doesn't do at the moment).
fields.summary: "Issues assigned to me" portlet has buggy link

fields.description: One thing that annoys me about JIRA is that I can't comment on a bug without going to a separate page that doesn't have even the bug description to remind me what I'm commenting about.  I usually middle-click the 'Comment' link, so I can refer back to the original issue.  Why not just put the comment box below the issue description and existing comments, like every other bugtracker does?
fields.summary: Comment field should be on ViewIssue page

fields.description: When adding an attachment to an issue, one can also create a comment, but there is no obvious relation between the comment and the attachment in the UI.  There ought to be a 'description' field specifically associated with the attachment, like Bugzilla has. A MIME type field wouldn't hurt either.
fields.summary: Attachments need associated descriptions

fields.description:
Fix the CVS Log handler according to jira-user email:


http://forums.atlassian.com/thread.jspa?forumID=46&threadID=3289&messageID=74973864#74973864
fields.summary: Improve CVS Log Handler

fields.description:
Hi 

Maybe I do not have a good understanding of jira yet, but the work process seems flawed in terms of standard software development mthodology.  A bug is reported by a client.  A bug is received and assigned.  A bug is resolved and assigned back to the project manager, QA or client for verification.  The client sets the resolved bug to verified.  This is the trigger or indicator that a bug can now be closed.  A resolved bug in jira must be reopend to be reassigned.  

Tom
fields.summary: work flow process - open closed

fields.description:
Hi

I see filters as reports really.  Most bug reporting systems allow a user to sort on specific criteria before making a report.  ie show me all issues sorted by issue number then by status etc.
fields.summary: Sorting on filters

fields.description:
Hi

Currently when you create an issue you have to create an issue then attach a file.  

Most software bugs are reported via screen shots.  Why not have them as one step instead of two to save the users time when submitting a bug.

Tom
fields.summary: Ability to attach a file in one step

fields.description:
I have configured an issue security scheme to hide certain "private" issues from customers. with this scheme the issues cannot be seen by customers as desired but they still appear in most, probably all lists. I've tested changelog, filters, 'fix-for-version' lists.

I'd like to habe the private issues completely invisible for unpriviledged users!
fields.summary: Private Issues show up in lists

fields.description: According to jira-user email from Karri Niemel (5/Sep).
fields.summary: Statistics not updated when issue created from email

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-2291].
  {panel}

In our environment we have multiple units that are responsible for maintaining documentation (specs, requirements, etc).  Most of these units store their information on servers local to them.  

In the current process, we have the ability to create attachments for tasks, but this causes several problems for us.

1)  We do not want to store duplicate documents.
2)  We would have to purchase larger harddrive systems to store all this information that is currently stored on other servers.
3)  The attachments can become outdated and would require dropping them and re-attaching the new documents.

The solution we would like to see implemented is to allow us to create links (with descriptions) to external resources.  Then the external units can continue to manage their documents per their process, and our users would always link to the most recent versions.

Thanks

When we upgrade JIRA or chnage to setup it would be erally handy to be able to email all jira users to notify them of the outage/change.

It would be nice to be abily to choose between all users or a particular group as some chanegs will only impact a subset of user.

This functionality would probably only be needed by the Administrator.

It would be really useful to have one of the following features added to JIRA, when creating a new issue :

1) Ability to attach docs to an issue during the create process. Therefore making this a one step process, rather than a two step process (and hence reducing the email notifications generated).

and/or

2) Ability to cut/paste pictures (e.g. screenshots) in to the description section of the issue.
fields.summary: Ability to add attachments when creating issue

fields.description:
One of our issues is exhibiting very worrying behaviour as follows:

The penultimate comment is not being displayed.  Eg, If we have 5 comments:

issue
c1
c2
c3
c4*
c5

The comment c4 does not get shown.  If we then add a new comment, c4 appears and c5 dissapears so we get:

issue
c1
c2
c3
c3
c4
c6

No c5!  This is causing us lots of grief at the moment because bug fixing audit trails (with things like workarounds) are dissapearing all over the place with no warning!

v2.4.1 has some howling bugs in I'm afraid (see my other recent bug report) - JRA-2272
fields.summary: Penultimate comment not displayed

I setup the Create issue handler so that i can create issues from emails.

What i noticed is that it does create the issue from the email, but it doesn't remove the email from the mailbox so it keeps creating the issue every minute until i manually deleted the email.

I would think that it would either delete the email from the mailbox or at least know what it grabbed so it doesn't keep creating the issue.

fields.description:
There is a bug in JIRA's 'project table' portlet, the effect of which is that JIRA appears to hang for certain users directly after login (accessing the dashboard page).  The JSP does not handle the case where the 'numofentries' portlet property is null, due to having upgraded from an earlier version when this property didn't exist.

The fix for 2.3, 2.4 and 2.4.1 is to copy the attached JSP to:

 - atlassian-jira/portlets/dashboard/projecttable.jsp (standalone distribution)
 - webapp/portlets/dashboard/projecttable.jsp (webapp distribution)

Versions of the JSP for JIRA 2.3 and 2.4.x are attached.

fields.description:
Currently you can only enter plain text into the text area's in JIRA. You have no way of specifying a piece of text to be bold/italic, preformatted or coloured.

Due to the circumstances we use JIRA in, it would be extreemly useful if we could say that a block is preformated, or should be displayed using a fixed width font (e.g. Courier New for displaying indented XML / code).

Various options are bulliten board style [b]..[/b] tags, or just regular XML parsed and rouge elements (e.g. script / iframe) ripped out. Although even script / iframe elements have their uses! (e.g. sourcing a js file to dynamically show progress of the latest xml output from a webpage).

Im not sure how you could achieve this, perhaps with custom fields where you specify if "tags" (or whatever you term them as), raw html, or just plain text is allowed. Also you could set things like the URI detector to be optionally selectable on free text fields.

To be honest, implementation isnt really my concern - just the ability is.
fields.summary: HTML Text Areas (comments / description / environment etc)

fields.description:
Provide explanation of JDK and where to get it (from the minimum requirements spec). 

See this email from a current user....

Hi Ben,

Thanks for your friendly email, a timely reminder for me. We have no time to evaluate this  month and possibly next, but certainly want to. We're using Seapine's Test track Pro right now and increasingly running into its limitations. A colleague recommended and was enamored with JIRA and that's how I came to download the evaluation version.

My initial observation on download was one of confusion as I'm no Java geek alas and your website at:

http://www.atlassian.com/software/jira/docs/v1.4/requirements.jsp

claims that for the standalone demo I need:

    Sun JDK 1.3 or above

But not only do I have no idea what this is, and find no further guidance on this web page, when I search for it on Google, the best I can come up with is:

http://java.sun.com/j2se/1.3/

which doesn't really satisfy me as it just adds more acronyms and confusion. Nevertheless I somehow downloaded:

j2sdk-1[1].4.2-nb-3.5-bin-windows.exe
j2re-1_3_1_09-windows-i586.exe

by following links from that page, but am frankly none the wise which, if any of these satisfies the "Sun JDK 1.3 or above" requirement.

I would be most grateful if you could shed some light on that for me, and would suggest you add the clarifications to your web site, and perhaps some guidance as to where a prospective client might lay hands on it. 

Cheers,

Bernd Wechner
SonarData Pty Ltd
bernd@sonardata.com
http://www.sonardata.com
Ph: +61 3 6231 5588 
Fax: +61 3 6234 1822
fields.summary: Provide explanation of JDK and where to get it

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-2250].
  {panel}

(from jira-user mailing list):

Hi All,

I wrote a quick and dirty little class to integrate JIRA with our
existing build notification process and figured I'd share it in case
anyone is looking to do something similar.  

Our build process is designed to send out an email when it is complete
and included in the email is all the issues that were fixed in that
build.  This is primarily for the benefit of our QA department.  Anyway I included a sample pic of what the email looks like (basically mimics JIRA).  The class also updates a custom field that we use for the build number.

There is some stuff that is specific to the way my company works so you would need to make some changes before using this.  I did try to
externalize most parameters into a props file, at least to make it
useable by multiple projects without recompiling, but there is still
stuff that needs changing (like the base JIRA url) in the code.

Anyway, if nothing else I figure its starting point for anyone else that might have the same kind of automatted processes.

-Chris

Ps.  You'll also need to grab the MailMessage class from
www.servlets.com.
fields.summary: Integrate JIRA with automated build process

fields.description:
(from Jason Horne via email):

I've set up POP servers and Create or Comment handlers which seem to work fine, with one exception: the issue ID in the subject line is case sensitive.  For example, we have a project with key "MVN", and an issue "MVN-5".  If we send an e-mail with "MVN-5" in the subject line, it adds the text of the message to MVN-5 as expected.  However, if the e-mail has "mvn-5", it just creates another brand new issue.

Is there a way to make it case insensitive?
fields.summary: Case-sensitive issue IDs with Create or Comment Handler

fields.description:
When JIRA starts in Tomcat (as in the standalone distro), the first thing it does is print these warnings:


log4j:WARN No appenders could be found for logger (org.apache.commons.digester.Digester).
log4j:WARN Please initialize the log4j system properly.

This does not affect subsequent operation, but is annoying and should be fixed.

---

The problem arose when JIRA migrated from Tyrex to JOTM.  Previously the webapp was responsible for obtaining a JTA implementation, but now it obtains one from the app server. The result of this change is that we now require commons-logging.jar in (and only in) the Tomcat classloader, but the actual logging implementation (log4j) is in the JIRA webapp. Somehow, commons-logging is detecting the presence of log4j, but not finding the log4j.properties file.
fields.summary: log4j warnings on startup

fields.description:
After discussing with some of our managers, we think the wording on the "Log Work" page is a little confusing, and should be changed from "Set a new estimate" to "Set estimated time remaining".

I may log 4 hours against an 8 hour task, but now know it will take me a total of 10 hours. So at first we thought one should log 4 hours, and "Set a new estimate" to 10 hours, which is incorrect -- it's actually estimated _time remaining_ on the task, not the task _estimate_. Sort of a difference between the thinking of a developer and a project manager.

Additionally, might be able to combine the "Leave existing estimate" and "Set estimated time remaining" into a single field, perhaps defaulting the original value? Not sure.
